section.title: Vectors in Euclidean space

definition.statement: The length of a vector \vec{x} is a unique scalar associated with \vec{x} denoted by \abs{\vec{x}}.

section.p: In compass-and-straight-edge geometry, there is no way to calculate the length of a vector, but it is possible to determine whether two vectors have the same length. The existence of a coordinate system (Cartesian coordinates, for example) allows us to define a formula for the length of a Euclidean vector.

definition.title: Euclidean length
definition.statement: The length of a vector \vec{x}=\vc{x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n}\in\R^n is given by \norm{\vec{x}} = \sqrt{x_1^2+x_2^2+\cdots+x_n^2}.

section.p: Vectors in the Euclidean plane and in Euclidean 3-space are generally represented as arrows with a tail at one point and a head at another. Two arrows in the plane represent equivalent vectors if the arrows lie along parallel lines, have the same length, and point in the same respective direction along each of their respective lines. The zero vector, which is the unique vector of length 0, is represented as a point at the origin.

listing.p: We can use the Sage arrow2d and arrow3d commands to demonstrate vectors.
listing.caption: The vector \vc{1,2}\in\R^2 and \vc{1,2,3}\in\R^3.

subsection.title: Geometric operations
subsection.p: The two operations which are necessary to turn a set of n-tuples into a n-dimensional vector space are addition and scalar multiplication, which are both demonstrated easily using geometric vectors.

subsubsection.title: Geometric vector addition
subsubsection.p: To add two vectors \vec{x} and \vec{y} geometrically, we begin by drawing both as arrows, with the tail of each at the origin. We then draw an equivalent vector to \vec{x} with its tail at the head of \vec{y} and an equivalent vector to \vec{y} with its tail at the head of \vec{x}. These four vectors will form the sides of a parallelogram; the diagonal arrow with its tail at the origin and its head at the opposite corner of the parallelogram is the vector sum \vec{x}+\vec{y}.

sage.input: @interact def _(x=input_box(default=(1,2), type=tuple), y=input_box(default=(2,-3), type=tuple)): s = (x[0]+y[0],x[1]+y[1]) xarr = arrow2d((0,0),x,color='blue') yarr = arrow2d((0,0),y, color='red') xparr = arrow2d(y,s, color='blue', linestyle='--') yparr = arrow2d(x,s, color='red', linestyle='--') sumarr = arrow2d((0,0),s,color=(0,.75,0),linestyle='--') show(xarr+yarr+sumarr+xparr+yparr)

subsubsection.title: Geometric scaling of vectors
subsubsection.p: The geometric scaling of a vector is actually the source of the term scalar; given a vector \vec{x} and a constant k, the scalar multiple of \vec{x} by k is the vector k\vec{x} with \abs{k\vec{x}}=k\abs{\vec{x}}, whose direction is the same as \vec{x} if k\gt 0 and whose direction is opposite \vec{x} when k\lt 0.
It should be clear that 0\vec{x}=\vec{0} is the zero vector for every \vec{x}.

subsection.title: Linear transformations in Euclidean geometry
subsection.p:
You can think of a linear transformation geometrically by considering the unit square, or its higher dimensional equivalent; the images of each of the standard basis vectors
\vec{e}_1 \amp = \vc{1,0,0,\ldots,0},
\vec{e}_2 \amp = \vc{0,1,0,\ldots,0},
\amp\vdots
\vec{e}_n \amp = \vc{0,0,0,\ldots,1}
are (roughly) the columns of the matrix representing the transformation.
